journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Lateral forces on tapered pistons – An overview

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Eizo Urata, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kanagawa University, Yokohama 221-8686, Japan. Email: jifujun65@yahoo.co.jp

abstract.p: The purpose of this article is to contribute to a more comprehensive overview of the lateral force on tapered pistons. Numerical analyses are carried out to evaluate the lateral force on a piston; the flow rate through the clearance is also calculated. The range of parameters, namely, length-to-diameter ratio, the taper and the eccentricity, covers almost all the applications that appear in fluid power engineering. The pressure distribution obtained by difference equations is verified using an iteration convergence test. The lateral force is obtained applying Simpson’s integral to the obtained pressure. Using the dimensionless lateral forces obtained using finite mesh sizes, an evaluation of the dimensionless lateral force for an infinitely fine mesh size is made. The numerical results coincide well with experiments reported in the literature. An approximate function is shown by expressing the dimensionless force with an accuracy of about 3% for a region of the taper and the length/diameter ratio appearing frequently in practice. Four types of difference equations that are derived from the laminar flow equation are compared with respect to necessary iteration numbers and accuracy of the results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In fluid power technology, the unexpected adhering of a valve piston to the bore of the valve (cylinder) is named as ‘hydraulic lock’.1 It is easily foreseen that such adhering may occur if solid contaminants in a fluid become stuck between the cylinder and the piston. Stringer2 reported that valve adhering due to fluid contaminants is resolved by suitable filtration of the fluid. A piston and a cylinder can become stuck together by chemicals: additives in hydraulic fluids or oxidation compound produced in working fluid.3 However, the adhering can sometimes occur even if a new and very clean fluid is used. An early classic study is the experiment and analysis by Sweeney,1,4 who found that the lock is caused by uneven pressure distribution in the clearance between the cylinder and piston. Since then, several techniques have been developed to avoid unexpected adhering.

The first method is to carve grooves around the lands of pistons, which makes the pressure around the circumference of the pistons more uniform.5 The grooves reduce the adhering force, but generate no force to return the pistons to the centre. However, this method is most widely applied to commercial valves because grooves are easily processed. Optimisation of the number and positions of the grooves has been studied by Milani,6 Schlemmer7 and Schlemmer and Murrenhoff.8

The second method is to make the valves vibrate slightly. The vibration keeps the fluid films between the pistons and cylinders; thus, it prevents the valves from sticking. This technique has been used in servo-valves in which a high-frequency, small-amplitude electric signal,9 known as dither, is added to the input electric signal.

The third method uses hydrostatic bearings that generate a force restoring the piston to the axially central position in the cylinder.10,11 The use of a hydrostatic bearing was already suggested by Bendy in the discussion for the article by Manhajm and Sweeney;4 they rejected the idea that the method could be too prone to contaminants in the fluids. Today, however, contamination control technology is well developed.12 This method has the advantage of being effective under the switching of high and low pressures at the ends of the piston land, and it works infallibly even in fluids of poor lubricity such as water.13

The fourth method is to give the piston land a positive taper so that the clearance decreases towards the low-pressure end of the piston. When the clearance along the axis is not constant and the piston central axis is off from the cylinder central axis, the pressure in the clearance generates a lateral force on the piston. If the clearance is increasing towards the low-pressure end, the force pushes the piston towards the cylinder wall, which results in the hydraulic lock.4,14–16 Conversely, converging clearance to the low-pressure end generates a force to return the piston to the centre.4,14,17,18

At very high pressures, elastic deformation of the cylinder creates a converging clearance which generates a centring force that was shown by experiments.19,20 The non-uniform pressure distribution around the circumference can also be generated by a right piston without taper if it tilts in the cylinder. This fact was pointed out by Blackburn,14 and precisely studied by Dransfield et al.21

The tapered land pistons, which are studied this article, have already aroused plenty of interest from researchers. Classic studies include the one-dimensional model by Blackburn,14 and the two-dimensional numerical analysis by Manhajm and Sweeney,4 Mannam,15 Mannam et al.17 and Hassey et al.16 These studies were made in eras when computing power was still quite low, so the oldest one is assumed to have been performed manually. Recently, Borghi22 carried out a numerical study for various combinations of parameters using a modern computer.

While numerical studies have been made by several researchers, the parameters investigated are yet limited and insufficient to describe the general properties of the lateral force. In this article, the lateral force is expressed in a dimensionless form as a function of the dimensionless parameters: taper, eccentricity, length-to-diameter ratio of pistons. For the taper and the eccentricity, all physically possible ranges are studied; the length/diameter ratio is studied from 0 to 8, which covers almost all engineering applications. The obtained results are given in the form of charts and tables, partly with approximate formulae. The accuracy of the calculated pressure distribution in the clearance and the lateral force are examined with respect to the convergence limit of the iterative procedure and the grid spacing.

sec.title: Basic equations
sec.p:
Figure 1 illustrates the piston and clearance considered in this article. The piston land has a uniform taper. The pressures at the left and right ends of the land are pL and pR, respectively, and it is assumed that pL > pR. The pressure difference, pL − pR, generates a fluid flow and creates a pressure distribution in the clearance. The pressure distribution can be determined using the following Reynolds equation since the clearance is assumed to be sufficiently narrow. (1)∂∂z(h312μ∂p∂z)+∂R∂θ(h312μ∂pR∂θ)=0 Figure 1.
Basic model of clearance.

The lateral force and the flow through the clearance can be calculated when the pressure distribution is known. Therefore, in what follows, the pressure distribution will be first determined; then, the lateral force and the flow rate will be estimated.

The assumptions in this study are as follows:
The fluid is Newtonian and viscosity is constant in the clearance.
The piston and cylinder are rigid; hence, there is no elastic deformation.
The axes of the piston and the cylinder are parallel.
The cross-sections of the piston and the cylinder are true circles.
The clearance between the piston and the cylinder is very small compared with the piston diameter.

In Figure 1(a), the piston centre is O and the cylinder centre is O′. The piston eccentricity e is positive when the piston is displaced to the left. The piston land has a positive taper in the picture; namely, the clearance becomes narrower on the right when a > 0. Since the clearance is very small compared with the piston radius, the clearance can be written (2)h=cL-acLzL+ecosθ where cL is the clearance at the midway of the land.

For general applicability of the results of the calculations, the variables and parameters are transformed to dimensionless quantities. The dimensionless equivalent of equation (2) is (3)hcL=H=1-aη+ɛ1(1-|a|)cosθ where (4)e/cL=ɛ, ɛ=ɛ1(1-|a|) (5)η=z/L By the above definition, the physically possible ranges of the axial coordinate and the parameters become (6)-1≤η≤1,-1≤a≤1,-1≤ɛ1≤1 Taking the lower pressure as the base, the dimensionless pressure becomes (7)P=p-pRpD where (8)pD=pL-pR Using these dimensionless quantities, equation (1) is rewritten as (9)∂∂η(H3∂P∂η)+(LR)2∂∂θ(H3∂P∂θ)=0 P is a periodic function of θ with period 2π; the boundary condition with respect to η is (10)P=1,at η=-1P=0,at η=1}

The studies in Manhajm and Sweeney,4 Blackburn14 and Borghi22 took the clearance at either end of the piston as the reference value. Consequently, negative and positive tapers were treated separately and the range of taper parameter became from zero to infinity. However, taking the coordinate origin at the midway of the land and the reference value as shown in Figure 1, a physically possible taper is expressed by a value lying between −1 and 1. When one end of the piston contacts with the cylinder, it is represented by (11)a=±1
The lateral force resulting from the pressure distribution is given by (12)F=-∫-LLdz∫02πpcosθd(Rθ)=-pDRL∫-11dη∫02πPcosθdθ
The reference force F0 is the product of pD and the projected area of the piston (13)F0=4pDRL
The dimensionless force is (14)FF0=f, f=-14∫-11dη∫02πPcosθdθ
The flow through the clearance is (15)Q=∫02π(-h312μ∂p∂z)Rdθ
The reference flow Q0 is the leakage flow through the clearance space with zero taper and zero eccentricity (16)Q0=πRcL3pD12μL
The dimensionless flow rate is defined by (17)q=QQ0=1π∫02π(-H3∂P∂η)dθ

sec.title: Analytical solutions
sec.p: The analytical solutions are available only for the two cases: limit of L/R goes to zero or infinity. The solutions for these cases are seen in the literature.14,15 Analytical solutions for these cases can also be obtained using the parameters defined in this article. These limit cases are necessary because they are used as reference values for numerical analysis and because they cannot be obtained by a numerical calculation program made for finite values of L/R.

sec.title: Long lands
sec.p: Suppose that the following inequality holds (18)L/R>>1
Then, the first term of equation (9) can be ignored and the equation will be reduced to (19)∂∂θ(H3∂P∂θ)=0
The solution of this equation satisfying the boundary condition and the law of mass conservation is (20)P=1-log[(1+a1-aη)23ɛ2+2(1-aη)23ɛ2+2(1+a)2]log[(1+a1-a)23ɛ2+2(1-a)23ɛ2+2(1+a)2]
Thus, the pressure is independent of angle θ; hence, the lateral force is zero. This means that the lateral force approaches zero when L/R goes infinity (21)f=f(L/R→∞,a,ɛ1)→0

The flow rate is constant with respect to η and is expressed by (22)q=6aɛ2log[(1+a1-a)23ɛ2+2(1-a)23ɛ2+2(1+a)2] Equations (20) and (22) are valid when ɛ≠0 (see Appendix 2 for derivation of equations (20) and (22)). Otherwise, the equations become invalid due to zero division. This zero division is avoided by substituting ɛ=0 into H in equations (3) and (19), and continuing the calculation. The results are (23)P=(1+a)2(1-η)[2-a(1+η)]4(1-aη)2 and (24)q=(1-a2)2

Figure 2 shows q of equation (22) taking a as abscissa and ɛ1 as parameter. As seen from equation (22), q is an even function with respect to a and ɛ1. Equation (22) becomes an indeterminate form at a = 0, which is resolved by the limit calculation of calculus. The indeterminate form corresponds to the singularity at a = 0, which is reflected as the cusp at a = 0 on the curves in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Dimensionless flow rate by equation (22).

Figure 3 shows the pressure distribution expressed by equations (20) and (23). The features of the pressure distribution are: (a) it becomes a straight line for a = 0; (b) the curve becomes concave for a negative a and convex for a positive a; (c) the pressure gradient becomes steeper when the clearance becomes narrower; and (d) the influence of ɛ1 is small compared with that of a. Figure 3.
Pressure distribution for η with infinite L/D.

sec.title: Short lands
sec.p: The assumption for this case is (25)L/R <<1
The lateral force for this case is found in the literature.13,14 The expressions using the parameters in this article are as follows.
Equation (9) is reduced to (26)∂∂η(H3∂P∂η)=0

The solution of this equation satisfying the boundary condition is (27)P=(1+a+ɛcosθ)24a(1+ɛcosθ)[1-(1-a+ɛcosθ)2(1-aη+ɛcosθ)2] Substituting equation (27) into equations (14) and (17) yields (28)f={0,(a=0)πaɛ1(1-|a|)21-ɛ12(1-|a|)2·11+1-ɛ12(1-|a|)2, (a≠0) and (29)q=12[2+3ɛ12(1-|a|)2-4a2+2a41-ɛ12(1-|a|)2]

The pressure expressed by equation (27) varies in the axial and circumferential directions and generates the lateral force. An example of pressure distribution calculated using equation (27) is illustrated in Figures 4 and 5; the example corresponds to a = −0.5 with ɛ1 = 0.5. The pressure distribution in the axial direction is similar to that shown in Figure 3, which corresponds to a very long land length. The pressure curves are concave for negative values of a. The pressure distribution in the circumferential direction shows a larger variation for a narrower clearance. Despite this distribution being a limit case of L/R approaching zero, it represents a similar tendency with curves for finite L/R ratios; this will be shown in the following section. Figure 4.
Pressure distribution for θ with infinite L/D.
Figure 5.
Pressure distribution for η with a = −0.5, ɛ1 = 0.5.

Figure 6 shows f expressed by equation (28). Since f is an odd function of a and of ɛ1, the curves are shown only for a > 0, ɛ1 > 0. This picture covers the full range of physically possible taper values. Figure 6.
a vs. f with L/R ≪ 1; parameter ɛ1.

Figure 7 illustrates f taking ɛ1 as abscissa and a as the parameter. When the absolute value of a is greater than 0.5, f is almost proportional to ɛ1. When a becomes smaller than 0.5, the non-linear property of f becomes apparent and the curves become concave upward. Figure 7.
ɛ1 vs. f with L/R ≪ 1; parameter a.

Although equations (22) and (29) are essentially different functions, the numerical difference of each q by these two functions is very small. Figure 8 shows the difference (equation (22) minus equation (29)). The numerical results in the following section lie between the two estimates by equations (22) and (29). Figure 8.
Dimensionless flow difference between R/L ≪ 1 and L/R ≪ 1.

sec.title: Method of pressure distribution calculation
sec.p: Pressure distribution for a finite non-zero L/R value can be obtained using a numerical method. Once the pressure distribution is found, the lateral force and the flow rate will be obtained using a commonly known algorithm whose accuracy is well explained in texts on numerical methods.23

About the study of the lateral force, three kinds of numerical methods appeared in literature. The first method transforms the Reynolds equation into a standard form of the second-order partial differential equation and then transforms it to a difference equation. Dransfield20 and Borghi22 used this method. The second method transformed the Reynolds equation to a linear combination of Laplacian of functions; the relaxation method for the standard square net is then applied. This method was used by Manhajm and Sweeney,4 and Mannam.15 The third method is to derive a finite difference equation directly from the Reynolds equation, which is used by Hassey et al.16

Although these methods are based on the continuity equation, the derived finite difference equations are different and the numerical results for a common grid size show the differences. However, the differences approach zero when the grid size is made finer. In the present numerical analysis, all these methods are examined. In what follows, a finite difference equation will be derived directly from the continuity principle, without using the Reynolds equation.

sec.title: Difference equation derived directly from the continuity principle
sec.p: Hereafter, this method is named the ‘direct method’ for abbreviation.
The pressure is calculated on the nodes, namely (30)P(i,j)=P(O)P(i,j-1)=P(L),P(i,j+1)=P(R)P(i-1,j)=P(T),P(i+1,j)=P(U)}

Referring to Figure 9 and omitting the common multiplication factor pDcL3/12/μ, the flow rates into the rectangle ABCDA through sides AB, BC, CD and DA are approximated by the following. (31)side AB:QAB=-2RΔθP(i,j)-P(i,j-1)LΔηH3(L') (32)side BC:QBC=-2LΔηP(i+1,j)-P(i,j)RΔθH3(U') (33)side CD:QCD=-2RΔθP(i,j+1)-P(i,j)LΔηH3(R') (34)side DA:QDA=-2LΔηP(i,j)-P(i-1,j)RΔθH3(T') Figure 9.
Nodes and grids.

Applying the law of mass conservation yields the following difference equation. (35)P(i,j)=H3(L')ZP(i,j-1)k2+H3(U')ZP(i+1,j) +H3(R')ZP(i,j+1)k2+H3(T')ZP(i-1,j) where (36)Z=k2[H3(L')+H3(R')]+H3(U')+H3(T') (37)k=(RΔθ)/(LΔη)
The numbers of grids (M and N) are related to the mesh sizes (Δη and Δθ) by (38)Δη=2/M, Δθ=2π/N

In equation (35), the point L′ is taken midway between O and L. Similarly U′, R′ and T′ are taken midway along the grid. These points do not automatically become the midway; they depend on the function H. ‘Selection of clearance estimating point’ section will discuss the basis for the selection. For the present basic equations (3) and (9), the midway gave a good result. The resulting finite equation coincides with that used by Hassey et al.,16 which is derived from the Reynolds equation.

sec.title: Calculation procedure
sec.p: The important issues in solving a partial differential equation with a numerical method are convergence and mesh sizes. In solving an elliptic-type differential equation using a finite difference approximation, iterative procedure forms the basic method. The iteration on a computer program easily becomes the Richardson type.24

The accuracy depends on the convergence and the mesh sizes. The convergence of the numerical result is indispensable. However, the convergence does not guarantee the accuracy of the result since the limit of the convergence changes with the mesh sizes. Making the mesh sizes finer can improve the accuracy. However, a finer mesh size increases the necessary iteration for convergence. Before starting iterative calculation, an initial set of function values is assumed on each node. The necessary iteration number strongly depends on the initial set. If the assumed initial set is close to the convergence limit, a very low number of iterations is sufficient, although such is simply a lucky guess.

sec.title: Convergence of iteration
sec.p: In an iterative procedure, closeness of consecutive results does not guarantee that convergence has been achieved, although the closeness is often used as the criterion to terminate the iteration.23 A reliable criterion to assure convergence to a limit is to produce two sequences of numerical results, one approaching the limit from above, the other from below. In the present problem, P at each node inside the boundary is greater than 0 and less than 1. Therefore, relaxation from initial condition P(i, j) = 1 for each (i, j) node inside the boundary generates a decreasing sequence (39)aK(i,j)=Kth iterated value starting fromP(i,j)=1for all internal(i,j) (40)1>a1(i,j)>a2(i,j)>…>aK(i,j)>P(i,j) Similarly, relaxation from P(i, j) = 0 for each (i, j) node inside the boundary generates an increasing sequence (41)bK(i,j)=Kth iterated value starting fromP(i,j)=0for all internal(i,j) (42)0<b1(i,j)<b2(i,j)<…<bK(i,j)<P(i,j) The difference of each term of these two sequences satisfies (43)cn(i,j)=an(i,j)-bn(i,j) (44)1≥c1(i,j)>c2(i,j)>…>cK(i,j)>0 If the required accuracy is E1, the iteration can be terminated when (45)maxi,jcK(i,j)≤E1 is satisfied. Throughout the following numerical study, E1 = 10−6 is used. Therefore, the accuracy of the calculated dimensionless pressure is 10−6.

sec.title: Acceleration factor (over-relaxation)
sec.p: The convergence of iteration in the relaxation method is usually very slow, although the method is stable against disturbances that might be incidentally induced during iteration. To improve the converging velocity, an acceleration factor ω is used; namely, instead of equation (35), the following formula is used. (46)Pn+1(i,j)=[H3(L')ZPn+1(i,j-1)k2 +H3(U')ZPn(i+1,j)+H3(R')ZPn(i,j+1)k2 +H3(T')ZPn+1(i-1,j)]ω-(ω-1)Pn(i,j) where the suffix n indicates the nth iteration.

The over-relaxation factor ω can make the iteration unstable. Figure 10 illustrates the convergence of max{cK(i, j)} with M = N = 60, a = 0.25 and ɛ1 = 1, L/R = 1 for various ω. When ω introduces instability, the sequence cK(i, j) may not become monotonic, and the convergence criteria (45) become invalid. Therefore, a suitable ω must be looked for by trial calculations. Figure 10.
Convergence with acceleration factor (ω).

When iteration is repeated, usually the result converges to a limit. An unusual case is divergence of the calculated results; in the determination of pressure distribution, divergence occurs when the acceleration factor ω is greater than 2. Instability will be observed when ω approaches 2. After trying other numerical conditions (N, M, a, ɛ1, L/R), ω = 1.9 is used as the standard value in this study. However, when instability is observed, calculations with reduced ω are repeated until a convergent result is obtained.

sec.title: Estimate of discretisation error
sec.p: The pressure distribution thus obtained can be used to estimate the lateral force; Simpson’s integral formula is applied first to the axial direction and then to the circumferential direction. (47)S1(i)=13Mcos(2πiN)×∑j=1M/2[P(i,2j-1)+4P(i,2j)+P(i,2j+1)] and (48)MfN=π3N∑i=1N/2[S1(2i-1)+4S1(2i)+S1(2i+1)] where MfN is the force estimated by M × N lattice.
The force thus obtained involves the discretisation error. The basic assumption to eliminate the discretisation error is (49)limM,N→∞MfN=f

However, practice of the calculation requires unlimited time. Therefore, an estimate of the limit with a finite number of calculations is necessary. A method of the estimate is as follows. First, set M = N; write fN instead of NfN. Then, build the following sequence. (50){fN,fN+K,…,fN+nK}

To estimate the limit of the sequence, rules governing the sequence must be found. An empirical method of finding rules governing a sequence is to build the difference sequence of the original sequence (51)yn=fN+(n+1)K-fN+nK

Figure 11 shows examples of the plot of the difference sequences for representative parameter combinations. This picture indicates the following relation. (52)logyn=logA-slog(nK) or, equivalently (53)yn=A·(nK)s Figure 11.
Difference sequence.

After calculations with n different mesh sizes, approximate values of A and s can be obtained by applying the least squares method. Then, equations (51) and (53) yield (54)fN+(n+1)K=fN+A∑t=1n1(tK)s Making n→∞ in the above equation yields (55)f=fN+AKs∑t=1∞1ts=fN+AKsζ(s) where ζ(s) is the Riemann zeta function. The second term of equation (55) is the correction that is greater than the difference between f and fN + (n + 1)K. Figure 11 indicates that fN is a monotonically increasing convergent sequence. A trial calculation taking N = M = K = 60 results in a relatively small correction; for L/R = 1 with a = 0.5, the correction term (= the second term of equation (55)) is 0.00135086, that is 0.81% of the estimated value of f (= left side of equation (55)).

Considering these results, numerical estimates of f are made using lattices of 60 × 60, 120 × 120, 180 × 180 and 240 × 240 for all the selected combinations of a and L/R. The selected values of a are from 0.05 to 0.95 with spacing 0.05; the selected values of L/R are from 0.1 to 1 with spacing 0.1 and for 1.2, 1.5, 2, 2.5 and 3, from 3 to 8 with spacing 1. Thus, calculations were carried out for 380 combinations of the two parameters keeping ɛ1 = 1. Over the calculated points, the average of s is 1.97; it increases for smaller a values; it takes a larger value when L/R is between 0.5 and 1.5; the maximum of s is about 2.46. The obtained values of A are approximately proportional to f. In addition to the above, calculations for ɛ1 = 0.95 and for other sample ɛ1 values with selected values of a and L/R were carried out to observe the characteristics of the lateral force.

sec.title: Numerical results and approximate formula for f
sec.p: This section briefly reports the results obtained for the pressure distribution, the lateral force, an approximate formula for f, the maximum value of f and the flow rate through the clearance.

sec.title: Pressure distribution
sec.p:
In general, the pressure changes in a finite land length are smaller than those shown in Figures 4 and 5 for zero length. As an example, the calculated pressure distribution for a = −0.5, ɛ1 = 0.5 and L/R = 1 is shown in Figures 12 and 13. Figure 12.
Pressure distribution in axial direction.
Figure 13.
Pressure distribution in circumferential direction.

sec.title: Lateral forces
sec.p: When a is negative, the lateral force pushes the piston away from the central position. Numerical calculation of f taking a and ɛ1 both positive is sufficient to draw an overall view of the lateral force since f is an odd function of a and ɛ1. The numerical results will be briefly explained below.

The most important diagram for the hydraulic lock is Figure 14 which shows the relation of a and f for various L/R with ɛ1 = 1. The diagram reveals the influence of the tapers and L/R ratios. Increase in L/R results in f decreasing to zero, which is the theoretical value for L/R = infinity. Figure 14.
Dimensionless lateral force for a with ɛ1 = 1.

All curves for f with different values of L/R meet at a = −1, 0 and 1; the values of f at these points are zero. The curves do not cross at any other point. A right piston without taper corresponds to a = 0; complete blocking of the flow passage corresponds to a = 1. Therefore, a peak value of lateral force must be observed between the interval 0 < a < 1. The maximum of f is about 0.27, found near a = 0.3 for L/R = 0 with ɛ1 = 1. When ɛ1 = 1, and when L/R approaches zero, the gradient of the a–f curve goes to infinity.

Figure 15 shows the dimensionless lateral force when the piston lies near the central position; ɛ1 = 0.1. The peak position of f for ɛ1 = 0.1 is moved right from that for ɛ1 = 1. Figure 15.
Dimensionless lateral force for a with ɛ1 = 0.1.

Figure 16 shows the influence of ɛ1 on f with L/R = 1 while Figure 6 the limiting values of f for L/R ≪ 1. Both figures show that a smaller ɛ1 gives a smaller f. Figure 16.
Dimensionless lateral force for eccentricity ɛ1 with L/R = 1.

Figure 17 shows the ɛ1–f characteristic. With the same value of a, the curvature of the ɛ1–f curve in Figure 17 is smaller than that shown in Figure 7. When L/R becomes larger, the curvature of the ɛ1–f curve decreases; at the same time, the magnitude of f becomes smaller. Figure 17.
Relation between ɛ1 and f.

sec.title: Approximate formula for f
sec.p: A formula expressing numerically obtained f will be useful for designers of valves when estimating a possible lateral force. Defining the lateral force by ɛ1 = 1 with f(L/R, a) and substituting ɛ1 = 1 into equation (28) yields (56)f(0,a)=πa2(1-|a|)(11-(1-|a|)2-1)
The lateral force for finite L/R is expressed using the multiplication factor w(L/R, a) determined by (57)f(L/R,a)=f(0,a)w(L/R,a)

A common idea for finding w is to express the numerical results by a polynomial of a and L/R. Polynomial approximations were tried by Hassey et al.16 and Borghi.22 Unfortunately, the number of terms in a polynomial rapidly increases when a smaller error or a wider applicable range of a variable is required. On the other hand, rational and modified rational functions can reduce the drawback. Equation (58) is an example of modified rational function approximation. (58)w≈w1=1+A4(L/R)b41+(L/R)b1(A1+A2ab2+A3ab3) where A1 = −0.16, A2 = −0.62, A3 = 0.77, A4 = 0.015, b1 = 1.95, b2 = 0.14, b3 = −0.65 and b4 = 0.04.
The error of this approximation is less than 3.2% for the parameter ranges (59)0.1<L/D<3,0.1<a<0.65

Figure 18 shows the percentile relative error of this approximation (60)E=100f(0,a)w1-ff Figure 18.
Relative error of equation (60).
For different ranges of L/R and a, other approximation functions can be made.

sec.title: Maximum of f
sec.p:
Unknown taper due to machining errors can generate a lateral force. When a and L/R are determined, f becomes maximum when ɛ1 = 1. The peak on a curve in Figure 14 gives the maximum of f with respect to a for the indicated L/R. The relationship between the peak values fmax and L/R is plotted in Figure 19. Designers of valves can estimate the worst case of hydraulic lock from this graph. This can also be used for load-carrying capacity when converging clearance is applied to journal bearings.17,18 A fit function for fmax is as follows. (61)fmax=0.25+0.16(L/R)0.93+0.56(L/R)+(L/R)2 Figure 19.
Maximum lateral force.
The accuracy (RMSE against the numerical value) of this formula is 6 × 10−4.

sec.title: Flow rate through the clearance
sec.p:
Flow rate calculation is carried out as follows: (a) numerical differentiation of P with respect to η; (b) then, numerical integration for the product of ∂P/∂η and H3 on a circumference. The five-point formula is used for the differentiation; Simpson’s formula is used for the integration. The obtained flow rate lies between the two theoretical values for L/R = 0 (equation (29)) and L/R = ∞ (equation (22)). Figure 20 shows (62)Δq=(qby numerical solution) -(qevaluated by equation(29)) for ɛ1 = 1. Figure 20.
Flow rate; deviation from L/R = 0.

The flow rate is larger for a larger L/R. However, its maximum is limited by the value for L/R = ∞, which is only 4% greater than that for L/R = 0. Therefore, an approximate value of the flow rate for any value of L/R can be estimated by equation (22) or equation (29) if the difference level is accepted.

sec.title: Selection of clearance estimating point
sec.p: To determine H in equation (35), suitable points L′, R′, T′ and U′ must be selected to obtain a better numerical result. The accuracy of numerical solutions can be estimated by comparing them with the exact solution.

The piston is assumed to be at the central position, i.e. ɛ1 = 0. Then, equation (9) is reduced to the following ordinary differential equation (63)ddη[(1-aη)3dPdη]=0 It has the following exact solution (64)P=(1+a)24a[1-(1-a)2(1-aη)2] Since equation (63) is one dimensional, index i is omitted and the finite difference formula (35) is reduced to the following. (65)P(j)=[H3(L')P(j-1) +H3(R')P(j+1)]/[H3(L')+H3(R')] L′ and R′ are defined as follows (66)ηL'=j-1-M/2-rL(M/2),ηR'=j-1-M/2+rR(M/2) The sum of rL and rR must be kept unity, namely, rL + rR = 1. Otherwise, the condition of mass conservation cannot be kept.

Numerical calculations taking M = 180, a = 0.25 for various rR are illustrated in Figure 21. The value of rR giving minimum error exists between 0.5 and 0.505; the difference between the errors for two rR values is about 10−6. Therefore, calculations in this article are carried out taking rR = 0.5. Figure 21.
Error by position selection of H.
The above example suggests that midway is a suitable selection, although it is by no means rigorous proof for two-dimensional clearances.

sec.title: Avoiding zero division in analytical solution in literature
sec.p: In early studies, estimates based on the infinitely short and long lands were made.14,15 These idealised cases partly reflect real cases. First, the pressure distribution in the infinitely short land is similar to the distribution from the numerical results for finite land lengths, which is observed when Figures 4 and 5 and Figures 12 and 13 are compared. Second, Figure 14 shows that the dimensionless lateral force on a finite-length piston lies between the two idealised models.

Substituting ɛ=ɛ1(1-|a|) into equation (28), the equation is transformed to equation (67), which is similar to the expressions that have appeared in literature.4,14–16,21,22 (67)f=πa2ɛ[11-ɛ2-1] This expression seems rather beautiful; however, it has the drawback of zero division by ɛ = −1, 0 and 1. Equation (28) is rather lengthy but it avoids the zero division.

sec.title: Relationship between the lateral force and the parameter a
sec.p: The definition of dimensionless clearance by equation (3) is a feature of this study. The normalised taper in literature4–22 is (68)τ=Difference of spool radii at both endsSmallest clearance Unfortunately, the range of this quantity is from 0 to infinity; infinity is always inconvenient for numerical studies. Moreover, equation (68) does not distinguish between positive and negative taper. The definition by equation (3) removes these drawbacks. The relation between τ and a in this article is (69)a=τ2+τ With this transformation, the interval [0,∞) of τ is projected onto the interval [0, 1) of a. The expression of clearance by equation (3) with a range of a from −1 to 1 facilitates an overview covering all possible tapers of a single-land piston.

A similar transformation to L/R, namely, such as L* = (L/R)/[positive constant + (L/R)] projects the infinite interval [0, inf.) of L/R to a finite interval [0, 1) of L*. However, it is difficult to find a physical or geometric meaning of the transformed variable; therefore, this article used the parameter L/R without transformation.

In the ‘Analytical solutions’ section, it was stated that f is an odd function of a and ɛ1. Figure 22 illustrates this situation. The force f is positive when a > 0 with ɛ1 > 0; hence, the force pushes the piston to reduce the eccentricity. In Figure 22, the thick and dashed curves express positive (ɛ1 > 0) and negative (ɛ1 < 0) eccentricity, respectively. This picture shows that a > 0 generates a centring force, and a < 0 generates an off-centring force that causes the hydraulic lock. Figure 22.
An overview of lateral force.

sec.title: Comparison with experimental results in literature
sec.p:
The pressure distribution in the clearance was measured by Manhajm and Sweeney.4 The numerical analysis of this study is applied to their experimental condition. Figure 23 shows the experimental value read from their picture (Fig. 12a in Manhajm and Sweeney4). While such experiment is very difficult, it coincides fairly well with the numerical analysis. Manhajm and Sweeney gave four numerically obtained lateral forces that are plotted in Figure 24; the curve is given by this study. Their results, which were probably obtained by hand calculation, are fairly correct. Figure 23.
Comparison with experiment by Manhajm and Sweeney4 (plot points are read out from Fig. 12 of their paper4 for their piston D/2/1; dimensions by notation this study: 2 L = 42.898 mm, L/R = 0.787 (≈π/4), a = 0.496, ɛ1 = 0.95.).
Figure 24.
Comparison with the numerical result by Manhajm and Sweeney.4

The lock force was measured by Manhajm and Sweeney,4 Dransfield et al.21 and Schlemmer and Murrenhoff.8 However, the force in the axial direction is influenced by the friction coefficient between the piston and the cylinder. The authors of the former two papers stated that the friction coefficient accompanied very small variance, while Schlemmer and Murrenhoff noted dispersion of the lock force due to the friction coefficient. Sasaki and Yamamoto3 reported that sticking accompanies the chemical action of additives and oxidation residue in oil; the lock force changes with time, after the piston is put in position. The present author believes that the Coulomb friction coefficient changes with the environmental condition. Therefore, the theoretically estimated lateral force will be compared with directly measured lateral forces, not forces in the axial direction divided by the friction coefficient. Mannum et al.17 measured the centring force using convergent clearances. Figure 25 compares their data (Figs 22–10 and 22–11 of Mannum et al. 17) with the numerical analysis in the ‘Numerical analysis’ section. This coincides well with the reported experimental results. Figure 25.
Comparison with experiment by Mannum et al.17

sec.title: Comparisons of finite difference equations
sec.p: To compare the suitability of the difference equations, numerical calculations similar to the ‘Numerical analysis’ section are carried out for the remaining three methods.
Method (a) is described in the ‘Numerical analysis’ section; the corresponding difference equation is equation (35); this equation coincides with those used by Hassey et al.16

Method (b) uses the standard form of an elliptic partial differential equation developed from the dimensionless Reynolds equation (9) in the following form. (70)∂2P∂η2+(LR)2∂2P∂θ2-3aH∂P∂η-3ɛ1sinθH(LR)2∂P∂θ=0 The corresponding difference equation is (71)P0=(BBPB+BTPT+BRPR+BLPL)/2(1+k2) where (72)BU=1-3πɛ1NHsinθ, BT=1+3πɛ1NHsinθBR=k2(1-3aMH), BL=k2(1+3aMH)} H and θ in equation (71) are evaluated at node (i, j). Dransfield20 and Borghi22 used this calculation scheme.

Method (c) transforms the dimensionless Reynolds equation to the following form. For shorter expression, the following differential operator is used. (73)∇R=∂2∂η2+(LR)2∂2∂θ2 Then, the dimensionless Reynolds equation is transformed to (74)∇R(H3P)+H3∇RP-P∇RH3=0 The difference equation derived from this equation is (O, B, T, R, L corresponds to nodes in Figure 9) (75)P0=CBPB+CTPT+CRPR+CLPL where (76)CR=HR3+H03ZC, CT=k2HT3+H03ZC,CL=HL3+H03ZC, CU=k2HU3+H03ZC, where (77)ZC=2H03(1+k2)+HR3+HL3+k2(HT3+HU3) The transformation to equation (74) is due to Southwell,25 which is used by Manhajm and Sweeney,4 Mannum15 and Mannum et al.15,17

Method (d) is now introduced in the following. The coefficient of P in the last term of equation (74) is developed in the following form, since H is a known function. (78)∇RH3=6H[a2+(LR)2ɛ2sin2θ] -3H2(LR)2ɛcosθ Substituting equation (78) into equation (74), the following difference equation is derived. (79)P0=DBPB+DTPT+DRPR+DLPL where (80)DR=HR3+H03ZD, DT=k2HT3+H03ZD,DL=HL3+H03ZD, DU=k2HU3+H03ZD where (81)ZD=4H03(1+k2)+s2{∇RH3}H=H0,θ=θ(i,j)

sec.title: Comparison of necessary calculation time
sec.p: Using the above four methods, the pressure distributions are calculated, and the number of iterations to reach the same convergence limit of pressure are compared.

This comparison is carried out for the 380 combinations of a and L/R with ɛ1 = 1. Table 1 compares the numbers of iterations necessary to reach the convergence limit, namely, equation (45) in the ‘Numerical analysis’ section with E1 < 10−6. Entries in the table are the sums of numbers of iterations for the calculated 380 combinations. Iterations in methods (a), (c) and (d) are conducted with acceleration factor ω = 1.9. The computing time is almost proportional to the total number of iterations because the calculation of coefficients of P is required only once and stored in the program. Table 1.
Sum of numbers of iterations over the calculation points.
Range a = (0.05–0.95), L/R = (0.1–8) a = (0.05–0.95), L/R = (0.1–1)
(grid M = N) 60–60 120–120 180–180 240–240 60–60 120–120 180–180 240–240
Method (a) 164,571 754,778 1,732,968 3,104,736 30,229 179,682 423,449 685,346
Method (b) a a a a 30,296 179,680 (923,871) (1,477,952)
Method (c) 164,579 754,752 1,732,941 3,104,712 30,245 179,675 423,436 685,332
Method (d) 164,576 754,751 1,732,939 3,104,705 30,242 179,674 423,437 685,332
Note: aindicates that various ω values were used and the count lost meaning. Numbers within parentheses were calculated with ω = 1.8.

Numbers of iterations by methods (a), (c) and (d) almost completely coincide at each calculating point. While the iteration numbers in the table is 104–106, differences between the three methods are less than 10. Therefore, they are practically equivalent.

This shows that the convergence becomes difficult for: (a) larger grid spacing, (b) smaller a, and (c) larger L/R. When acceleration factor is reduced, the iteration can converge; however, for the reduced acceleration factor, the necessary iteration time increases rapidly, as shown in method (a) (Figure 10). Moreover, suitable acceleration factor must be sought by trial. Therefore, in computation stability and the computing time, method (b) is inferior to others.

sec.title: Error estimate of the calculated dimensionless force
sec.p: Difference between the f value in the ‘Numerical results and approximate formula for f’ section and the entries in Table 2 becomes largest at a = 0.95, L/R = 0.8, and its magnitude is 0.00117. In usual applications, a rarely exceeds 0.5 and L/R rarely exceeds 3. In this range, the entries in Table 2 are accurate to 0.01%.

Numerical study for equation (1) had already begun in the classic work of Manhajm and Sweeney.4 In that age, computer was not available and the numerical study required heavy work; so, the numerical calculation was made only for a few parameter combinations. However, their numerical results fairly coincide with this study. Numerical results by Hassey et al.6 show a rather large discrepancy from the present result. Relatively recently, Borghi22 made numerical analysis whose results are about 1–10% larger than the present results.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The study started from defining dimensionless variables and parameters. The dimensionless lateral force and the dimensionless flow rate are determined by dimensionless parameters: taper parameter a, eccentricity ɛ1 and length/radius ratio of the pistons L/R.
A method examining convergence of iteration is introduced and applied to the pressure calculation at every node.
Two methods to estimate the lateral force in limit of infinitely small grid spacing are discussed.
Four kinds of difference equations for analysing the pressure distribution are compared in the goodness for numerical analysis.
Analytical solutions of the basic equation can be obtained only for limited values of parameters L/R, ɛ1 and a. For the general combinations of the parameters, a numerical analysis was carried out, whose results are shown by graphs and tables.
A function approximating the dimensionless force is given, whose accuracy is 3.2% for 0.1 < L/D < 3 with 0.1 < a < 0.6.
The lateral force function f is an odd function of a and ɛ1; it has positive or negative non-linear spring characteristic with respect to ɛ1 corresponding to positive or negative a. The function f is zero at a = −1, 0 and + 1 for all ɛ1 and L/D. It has an extremum in the intervals of a of (−1, 0) and (0, 1).
The dimensionless flow rate is an even function with respect to a and ɛ1. The relative change of dimensionless flow rate by change of L/R from 0 to infinity is smaller than 4%.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Derivation of equations (20) and (22)
sec.p: Integrating equation (19) yields (84)P=g1(η)+g2(η)∫dθ(1-aη+ɛcosθ)3 where g1(η) and g2(η) are arbitrary functions of η. While P is a periodic function of θ (85)∫02πdθ(1-aη+ɛcosθ)3≠0 Hence, equation (84) holds only when (86)g2(η)≡0 Then, equation (84) is reduced to (87)P=g1(η)

A line integral of equation (1) on a complete circumference of the piston in Figure 1 is (88)∂∂z∫02π(h312μ∂p∂z)dθ+[h312R2μ∂P∂θ]02π=0 The second term on the left side of equation (88) is zero because h and ∂p/∂θ are periodic functions of θ. Therefore, the first term is also zero. Referring to the definition of Q (89)Q=∫02π(-h312μ∂p∂z)Rdθ=RpDcL312μL∫02π(-H3∂P∂η)dθ Substituting (87) into (89) yields (90)q=QQ0=1π∫02π(-H3dg1dη)dθ=-J(η)dg1dη where (91)J(η)=1π∫02πH3dθ=(1-aη)[3ɛ2+2(1-aη)2] Since q is constant with respect to η, equations (87) and (90) result in (92)P=-q∫dη(1-aη)[3ɛ2+2(1-aη)2]+C The integral constant C is eliminated by performing integration and applying the boundary condition P = 1 at η = −1; the result is (93)P=1-q6aɛ2log[(1+a1-aη)23ɛ2+2(1-aη)23ɛ2+2(1+a)2] The boundary condition P = 0 at η = 1 results in (94)q=6aɛ2log[(1+a1-a)23ɛ2+2(1-a)23ɛ2+2(1+a)2] Equation (94) is equation (22); substituting (94) into (93) yields equation (20).
